EM.content: Derrida’s attention to system and structure, la réduction du sens, neither restores classical motifs nor erases them > rather, determining possibility du sens on basis of “formal” organization which in itself has no sens: a critique [sic] of phenomenologies (Husserl, Hegel), which aspire for une réduction au sens
EM.linkedContent: Derrida’s attention to system and structure, la réduction du sens, neither restores classical motifs nor erases them > rather, determining possibility du sens on basis of “formal” organization which in itself has no sens: a critique [sic] of phenomenologies (Husserl, Hegel), which aspire for une réduction au sens

SEC.content: careful use of “ideological” in relation to Condillac: theory of sign as representation of idea, which represents a perceived thing; communication vehiculates a representation as ideal content (which will be called meaning); writing as species w/in genus of communication
SEC.linkedContent: careful use of “ideological” in relation to Condillac: theory of sign as representation of idea, which represents a perceived thing; communication vehiculates a representation as ideal content (which will be called meaning); writing as species w/in genus of communication

SEC.content: Husserl on possibility of absence of referent: 1) “sky is blue” is understood w/ out presence of sky 2) absence of signified, possible crisis of meaning: a) manipulate symbols b) statements can have meaning w/out objective signification, i.e. “square circle” c) Sinnlosigkeit or agrammaticality, i.e. “green is or,” “abracadabra”
SEC.linkedContent: Husserl on possibility of absence of referent: 1) “sky is blue” is understood w/ out presence of sky 2) absence of signified, possible crisis of meaning: a) manipulate symbols b) statements can have meaning w/out objective signification, i.e. “square circle” c) Sinnlosigkeit or agrammaticality, i.e. “green is or,” “abracadabra”

SEC.content: Husserl uses above to rigorously dissociate sign or expression (Ausdruck) as signifying sign from a sign meaning something (bedeutsame Zeichen)
SEC.linkedContent: Husserl uses above to rigorously dissociate sign or expression (Ausdruck) as signifying sign from a sign meaning something (bedeutsame Zeichen)

SEC.content: Husserl’s interest is in purely logical grammar not pure grammar > “the green is or,” unacceptable in context determined by a will to know, still signifies an example of agrammaticality
SEC.linkedContent: Husserl’s interest is in purely logical grammar not pure grammar > “the green is or,” unacceptable in context determined by a will to know, still signifies an example of agrammaticality

SEC.content: in French “le vert est ou” can become “le vert est où” or “le verre est où”
SEC.linkedContent: in French “le vert est ou” can become “le vert est où” or “le verre est où”

SEC.content: semantic horizon exceeded or punctured (crevé) by dissemination not polysemia
SEC.linkedContent: semantic horizon exceeded or punctured (crevé) by dissemination not polysemia

VM.content: would return to intentional phenomenon acquiesce to violence of fact, is there thus an irreducible zone of factuality, an original, transcendental, preethical violence? > would it be tied to phenomenality itself & possibility of language? embedded in root of meaning & logos
VM.linkedContent: would return to intentional phenomenon acquiesce to violence of fact, is there thus an irreducible zone of factuality, an original, transcendental, preethical violence? > would it be tied to phenomenality itself & possibility of language? embedded in root of meaning & logos

VP.content: the more the signifier is ideal, more it augments potency of repetition of presence, the more it protects, preserves, reserves and capitalizes on sense
VP.linkedContent: the more the signifier is ideal, more it augments potency of repetition of presence, the more it protects, preserves, reserves and capitalizes on sense

VP.content: knowledge as norm, intuition adequate to its object, already opened by promise, telos, in truth, the pro-visional [difference btwn intuition/intention] as essence of meaning (vouloir-dire), discourse adheres to discursive essence when false, attains its entelechy when true
VP.linkedContent: knowledge as norm, intuition adequate to its object, already opened by promise, telos, in truth, the pro-visional [difference btwn intuition/intention] as essence of meaning (vouloir-dire), discourse adheres to discursive essence when false, attains its entelechy when true

VP.content: “pure logical grammar,” le sens n’attend pas la vérité insofar as it expects it (en tant qu’il l’attend)
VP.linkedContent: “pure logical grammar,” le sens n’attend pas la vérité insofar as it expects it (en tant qu’il l’attend)

VP.content: differance thought prior to or from presence tells us to interrogate presence w/in closure of knowledge > it must also be thought otherwise: dans l’ouverture d’une question inouïe n’ouvrant ni sur un savoir ni sur un non-savoir comme savoir à venir, approaching that on basis of which sa clôture announces/decides itself: openness of this question doesn’t belong to system of vouloir-dire
VP.linkedContent: differance thought prior to or from presence tells us to interrogate presence w/in closure of knowledge > it must also be thought otherwise: dans l’ouverture d’une question inouïe n’ouvrant ni sur un savoir ni sur un non-savoir comme savoir à venir, approaching that on basis of which sa clôture announces/decides itself: openness of this question doesn’t belong to system of vouloir-dire

FSW.content: distinction of force & meaning is derivative in relation to archi-trace
FSW.linkedContent: distinction of force & meaning is derivative in relation to archi-trace

PPHS.content: for Derrida, contents of semiology cannot be exhausted by the metaphysical theory which regulates bedeuten (meaning) by the telos of speech
PPHS.linkedContent: for Derrida, contents of semiology cannot be exhausted by the metaphysical theory which regulates bedeuten (meaning) by the telos of speech

SH.content: in shibboleth (river), there’s suspension of meaning, almost opposite of phenomenological “epokhe,” which preserves meaning > those who couldn’t pronounce “shi” marked themselves as unable to remark a mark thus coded
SH.linkedContent: in shibboleth (river), there’s suspension of meaning, almost opposite of phenomenological “epokhe,” which preserves meaning > those who couldn’t pronounce “shi” marked themselves as unable to remark a mark thus coded

SH.content: Babel w/in a single language, shibboleth marks multiplicity in language, insignificant difference as condition of meaning
SH.linkedContent: Babel w/in a single language, shibboleth marks multiplicity in language, insignificant difference as condition of meaning

SH.content: insignificance of language, takes on meaning in relation to a place (border, house, threshold) > formation of alliances, codes, contracts
SH.linkedContent: insignificance of language, takes on meaning in relation to a place (border, house, threshold) > formation of alliances, codes, contracts

SH.content: poet is provoked, constituted, by the hour, its caesuras > poetic rhythm or spacing at heart of origin of meaning, meaning of language
SH.linkedContent: poet is provoked, constituted, by the hour, its caesuras > poetic rhythm or spacing at heart of origin of meaning, meaning of language

F.content: via Abraham and Torok, no meaning can come into being w/out topography
F.linkedContent: via Abraham and Torok, no meaning can come into being w/out topography

F.content: Abraham and Torok: topos & force attempt the impossible, to grasp through language source from which language emanates
F.linkedContent: Abraham and Torok: topos & force attempt the impossible, to grasp through language source from which language emanates

WM.content: signifier as sensory metaphor & signified as meaning (sens) use same root (sensus, Sinn) > what permitted the sensory to be removed from the senses?
WM.linkedContent: signifier as sensory metaphor & signified as meaning (sens) use same root (sensus, Sinn) > what permitted the sensory to be removed from the senses?

WM.content: for Aristotle, onoma can be both verbs & nouns, anything that has phōnē sēmantikē, anything that has intelligible meaning outside syntax, not a syncategorem [see p. 234n on Leibniz]
WM.linkedContent: for Aristotle, onoma can be both verbs & nouns, anything that has phōnē sēmantikē, anything that has intelligible meaning outside syntax, not a syncategorem [see p. 234n on Leibniz]

WM.content: Fontanier: prepositions, conjunctions, adverbs not tied to substantive idea, just ways of seeing
WM.linkedContent: Fontanier: prepositions, conjunctions, adverbs not tied to substantive idea, just ways of seeing

WM.content: Aristotle: noun as element of metaphor, first semantic unity, smallest signifying element, composite phōnē sēmantikē, each of its elements are insignificant (asēmos) w/out meaning; noun is different from verb only in atemporality
WM.linkedContent: Aristotle: noun as element of metaphor, first semantic unity, smallest signifying element, composite phōnē sēmantikē, each of its elements are insignificant (asēmos) w/out meaning; noun is different from verb only in atemporality

WM.content: Aristotle’s definition of noun, the element of metaphor, is a theory of the name, articulated w/ ontology > value of metaphor systematically chained to values of discourse, voice, meaning, resemblance, or to logos, phōnē sēmantikē, sēmainein, onoma, mimēsis, homoiosis
WM.linkedContent: Aristotle’s definition of noun, the element of metaphor, is a theory of the name, articulated w/ ontology > value of metaphor systematically chained to values of discourse, voice, meaning, resemblance, or to logos, phōnē sēmantikē, sēmainein, onoma, mimēsis, homoiosis

WM.content: for Aristotle, poet (man of metaphor) is btwn sophist and philosopher: multiplies meaning, not for sake of deception, but to return to identity of meaning; philosopher finds truth of meaning, beyond signs and names
WM.linkedContent: for Aristotle, poet (man of metaphor) is btwn sophist and philosopher: multiplies meaning, not for sake of deception, but to return to identity of meaning; philosopher finds truth of meaning, beyond signs and names

WM.content: most invariable characteristic of concept of metaphor: unity/continuity of meaning dominates play of syntax, subordination of syntax
WM.linkedContent: most invariable characteristic of concept of metaphor: unity/continuity of meaning dominates play of syntax, subordination of syntax

DS.content: concept of history has lived on possibility of meaning, on past/present/promised presence of meaning & truth > outside this system, concept of history reinscribed elsewhere, strategically
DS.linkedContent: concept of history has lived on possibility of meaning, on past/present/promised presence of meaning & truth > outside this system, concept of history reinscribed elsewhere, strategically

DS.content: thematism leaves out formal, phonic, graphic “affinities,” ignores play that takes word apart > thematism gathers semes linked by meaning (or signified concept)
DS.linkedContent: thematism leaves out formal, phonic, graphic “affinities,” ignores play that takes word apart > thematism gathers semes linked by meaning (or signified concept)

DS.content: “sure revelation of meaning” > hymen w/out fold, marriage w/out difference
DS.linkedContent: “sure revelation of meaning” > hymen w/out fold, marriage w/out difference

DS.content: [Derrida comes back to i] reads little point as a decapitation right next to castrated pike > capital I (disseminates unity of meaning), ego, ice, écho—plus-je > (I + Dé)irisation
DS.linkedContent: [Derrida comes back to i] reads little point as a decapitation right next to castrated pike > capital I (disseminates unity of meaning), ego, ice, écho—plus-je > (I + Dé)irisation

OS.content: question of meaning (sens) always posed w/in closure of metaphysics: sens (meaning, essence) governed by ousia as presence, as act, as end of movement, energeia (the sens of time thought on basis of present as nontime, as Being)
OS.linkedContent: question of meaning (sens) always posed w/in closure of metaphysics: sens (meaning, essence) governed by ousia as presence, as act, as end of movement, energeia (the sens of time thought on basis of present as nontime, as Being)

OS.content: for Bataille, process of preserving meaning is “vulgar”; Heidegger would agree [?]: meaning linked to metaphysical closure
OS.linkedContent: for Bataille, process of preserving meaning is “vulgar”; Heidegger would agree [?]: meaning linked to metaphysical closure

OS.content: via Aristotle, a now cannot co-exist w/ another now, its double, can only succeed it: only a single, same now can coexist: this is meaning, sense itself, united to presence
OS.linkedContent: via Aristotle, a now cannot co-exist w/ another now, its double, can only succeed it: only a single, same now can coexist: this is meaning, sense itself, united to presence

POS.content: metaphysics always attempts to uproot presence of meaning from differance
POS.linkedContent: metaphysics always attempts to uproot presence of meaning from differance

POS.content: from perspective of expressivism, text is nonsignifying, from perspective of differance, text produces all signification, “only nonexpressivity can signify,” “interiority” of meaning already worked over by its own exteriority
POS.linkedContent: from perspective of expressivism, text is nonsignifying, from perspective of differance, text produces all signification, “only nonexpressivity can signify,” “interiority” of meaning already worked over by its own exteriority

POS.content: metaphysical concept of history: meaning developing itself in straight, circular line
POS.linkedContent: metaphysical concept of history: meaning developing itself in straight, circular line

GSP.content: phenomenologist as “true positivist”: self-effacing before originality, primordiality of meanings > faithful comprehension of phenomenologist dispels shadow of a choice (might even say Husserl attuned to historicity of meaning, possibility of its becoming)
GSP.linkedContent: phenomenologist as “true positivist”: self-effacing before originality, primordiality of meanings > faithful comprehension of phenomenologist dispels shadow of a choice (might even say Husserl attuned to historicity of meaning, possibility of its becoming)

GSP.content: in late Husserl, [quasi-Hegelian teleological reason] movement of meaning can only be a norm/value not essence
GSP.linkedContent: in late Husserl, [quasi-Hegelian teleological reason] movement of meaning can only be a norm/value not essence

FS.content: in structuralism, content (living energy of meaning) is neutralized by form > they’ll say this is the author’s responsibility before the critic’s
FS.linkedContent: in structuralism, content (living energy of meaning) is neutralized by form > they’ll say this is the author’s responsibility before the critic’s

FS.content: to write is the impossibility of making meaning precede writing: it is to lower meaning while elevating inscription
FS.linkedContent: to write is the impossibility of making meaning precede writing: it is to lower meaning while elevating inscription

FS.content: it’s because writing is inaugural that it is dangerous and anguishing, doesn’t know where it’s going, essential precipitation toward meaning that it constitutes—is its future
FS.linkedContent: it’s because writing is inaugural that it is dangerous and anguishing, doesn’t know where it’s going, essential precipitation toward meaning that it constitutes—is its future

FS.content: meaning must await being said/written in order to inhabit itself [Husserl teaches this]
FS.linkedContent: meaning must await being said/written in order to inhabit itself [Husserl teaches this]

FS.content: attempt-to-write, moment of overflow (can’t be understand via voluntarism): when play of meaning overflows signification, which is always enveloped by limits of nature, life, soul
FS.linkedContent: attempt-to-write, moment of overflow (can’t be understand via voluntarism): when play of meaning overflows signification, which is always enveloped by limits of nature, life, soul

O.content: absolute knowledge present at 0 point of philosophical exposition: saturate text w/ meaning (sens), teleologically equate it [the text?] w/ its (sa) conceptual tenor
O.linkedContent: absolute knowledge present at 0 point of philosophical exposition: saturate text w/ meaning (sens), teleologically equate it [the text?] w/ its (sa) conceptual tenor

O.content: signifier sublated in process of meaning (the signified) > Hegel’s dialectic
O.linkedContent: signifier sublated in process of meaning (the signified) > Hegel’s dialectic

O.content: logos spermatikos, philosophy of the seed, romanticism, myth of semantic depth, genetic pro-gram [quoting from OG]
O.linkedContent: logos spermatikos, philosophy of the seed, romanticism, myth of semantic depth, genetic pro-gram [quoting from OG]

TB.content: sacred text is transferability making its translation untranslatable
sacred text (absolute text): pas de sens (not poverty of meaning, but no meaning that would be itself) > sacred text surrenders itself to translation; commands right away the translation it refuses
TB.linkedContent: sacred text (absolute text): pas de sens (not poverty of meaning, but no meaning that would be itself) > sacred text surrenders itself to translation; commands right away the translation it refuses

CHM.content: all discourse, philosophy, must escape madness in fact/principle if it is to have intelligible meaning (discourse must carry normality w/in itself) > not a defect linked to determined historical structure but essential universal necessity > the meaning of meaning
CHM.linkedContent: all discourse, philosophy, must escape madness in fact/principle if it is to have intelligible meaning (discourse must carry normality w/in itself) > not a defect linked to determined historical structure but essential universal necessity > the meaning of meaning

CHM.content: subversion of madness as natural comfort, prephilosophical confidence
CHM.linkedContent: subversion of madness as natural comfort, prephilosophical confidence

CHM.content: Freud’s latent content as danger to all historians of meaning [cf. p. 44]
CHM.linkedContent: Freud’s latent content as danger to all historians of meaning [cf. p. 44]

CHM.content: all history can only be the history of meaning
CHM.linkedContent: all history can only be the history of meaning

CHM.content: no history except of rationality/meaning: reappropriation of negativity—or forgets it (same thing) > history of truth, history of economy of negative: negativity not positive truth is the nonhistorical capital of history
CHM.linkedContent: no history except of rationality/meaning: reappropriation of negativity—or forgets it (same thing) > history of truth, history of economy of negative: negativity not positive truth is the nonhistorical capital of history

RGE.content: Lordship’s putting at stake of life (mettre en jeu, Daransetzen des Lebens) has meaning, it’s a moment in constitution of meaning, presentation of essence, truth
RGE.linkedContent: Lordship’s putting at stake of life (mettre en jeu, Daransetzen des Lebens) has meaning, it’s a moment in constitution of meaning, presentation of essence, truth

RGE.content: for history (that is, meaning) to form a continuous chain, to be woven (se trame), master must experience his truth (éprouve sa vérité) (must stay alive once raised above life)
RGE.linkedContent: for history (that is, meaning) to form a continuous chain, to be woven (se trame), master must experience his truth (éprouve sa vérité) (must stay alive once raised above life)

RGE.content: conservation of Aufhebung: circulation & self-reproduction as reproduction of meaning
RGE.linkedContent: conservation of Aufhebung: circulation & self-reproduction as reproduction of meaning

RGE.content: a laughter that never appears, exceeds phenomenality, the absolute possibility of meaning
RGE.linkedContent: a laughter that never appears, exceeds phenomenality, the absolute possibility of meaning

RGE.content: that there must be meaning, that nothing must be definitely lost in death, that Hegel refers to death as “abstract negativity” > Bataille finds all this laughable: submission to self-evidence of meaning, to its imperative, to its work, to its deferred enjoyment, to its seriousness
RGE.linkedContent: that there must be meaning, that nothing must be definitely lost in death, that Hegel refers to death as “abstract negativity” > Bataille finds all this laughable: submission to self-evidence of meaning, to its imperative, to its work, to its deferred enjoyment, to its seriousness

RGE.content: this submission is essence & element of Hegelian ontologics
RGE.linkedContent: this submission is essence & element of Hegelian ontologics

RGE.content: le comique absolu, c’est l’angoisse devant la dépense à fonds perdus, devant le sacrifice absolu du sens: sans retour et sans réserve
RGE.linkedContent: le comique absolu, c’est l’angoisse devant la dépense à fonds perdus, devant le sacrifice absolu du sens: sans retour et sans réserve

RGE.content: Kant & Hegel revealed most permanent philosophical determinations of negativity (truth, history, meaning, time, ideality) > their revolution: taking negative seriously, giving meaning to its labor
RGE.linkedContent: Kant & Hegel revealed most permanent philosophical determinations of negativity (truth, history, meaning, time, ideality) > their revolution: taking negative seriously, giving meaning to its labor

RGE.content: servility/work as desire for meaning, techne as unfolding of truth > how writing of lordship (which seeks to maintain trace) becomes writing of servility (for Bataille)
RGE.linkedContent: servility/work as desire for meaning, techne as unfolding of truth > how writing of lordship (which seeks to maintain trace) becomes writing of servility (for Bataille)

RGE.content: writing of sovereignty and general economy are similar: 1) both sciences 2) both relate objects to destruction, w/out reserve, of meaning > neither are sovereignty itself, “this loss,” but the “relation to the loss of meaning”
RGE.linkedContent: writing of sovereignty and general economy are similar: 1) both sciences 2) both relate objects to destruction, w/out reserve, of meaning > neither are sovereignty itself, “this loss,” but the “relation to the loss of meaning”

RGE.content: Bataille designates (as never before) the transgressive relationship that links world of meaning to world of nonmeaning
RGE.linkedContent: Bataille designates (as never before) the transgressive relationship that links world of meaning to world of nonmeaning

Gii.content: everything Heidegger says about man takes on meaning and value w/in oppositional limit to animal (it is dogmatic and serious)
Gii.linkedContent: everything Heidegger says about man takes on meaning and value w/in oppositional limit to animal (it is dogmatic and serious)

Gii.content: man’s hand infinitely removed from prehensile organs through the abyss of its being “durch einen Abgrund des Wesens”
Gii.linkedContent: man’s hand infinitely removed from prehensile organs through the abyss of its being “durch einen Abgrund des Wesens”

EJQB.content: the encounter (rencontre) is separation (breaks unity of Being by welcoming [accueillant] other into source of meaning) > contredit la “logique,” dans le fragile chaînon du “est”
EJQB.linkedContent: the encounter (rencontre) is separation (breaks unity of Being by welcoming [accueillant] other into source of meaning) > contredit la “logique,” dans le fragile chaînon du “est”

EJQB.content: only possible to say this by conceptualizing meaning, which is exile from Being, Being never is, never shows itself, never present, is never now
EJQB.linkedContent: only possible to say this by conceptualizing meaning, which is exile from Being, Being never is, never shows itself, never present, is never now

EJQB.content: “entre le chair trop vive de l’événement littéral et la peau froide du concept court le sens”
EJQB.linkedContent: “entre le chair trop vive de l’événement littéral et la peau froide du concept court le sens”

D.content: moment of present meaning: their “content” only surface effect into which you tombez sans cesse, fascinés by appearance
D.linkedContent: moment of present meaning: their “content” only surface effect into which you tombez sans cesse, fascinés by appearance

HST.content: for Levinas, when I mourn, I feel responsible, I murder: “my own,” those I believe I killed, I love > ineluctable empire of phantasm at origin of meaning [Blanchot also links thought of death to murder]
HST.linkedContent: for Levinas, when I mourn, I feel responsible, I murder: “my own,” those I believe I killed, I love > ineluctable empire of phantasm at origin of meaning [Blanchot also links thought of death to murder]

C.content: [la cartouche is a cartridge] dissemination of cartouches/cartridges (en tous sens, en tout genre) never exhausts a total > no total of meaning and genres (masculine/feminine)
C.linkedContent: [la cartouche is a cartridge] dissemination of cartouches/cartridges (en tous sens, en tout genre) never exhausts a total > no total of meaning and genres (masculine/feminine)

LI.content: [re: Sarl and I] our common and minimal code has been the existence & effects of the code > [from SEC] context as protocol of code, mark doesn’t have meaning outside context—there’s only contexts w/out any center, absolute anchoring (ancrage)
LI.linkedContent: [re: Sarl and I] our common and minimal code has been the existence & effects of the code > [from SEC] context as protocol of code, mark doesn’t have meaning outside context—there’s only contexts w/out any center, absolute anchoring (ancrage)

LI.content: always repression in stabilizing determination of a context, repression at origin of meaning, an irreducible violence > can’t say it’s “bad”
LI.linkedContent: always repression in stabilizing determination of a context, repression at origin of meaning, an irreducible violence > can’t say it’s “bad”

TN.content: as if “touch in itself” were touching blood [Nancy’s self-expulsion] > rapport entre le sang et le sens, entre le ‘coup de sens’ et le ‘coup de sang’ [sens, sang, cent, sans]
TN.linkedContent: as if “touch in itself” were touching blood [Nancy’s self-expulsion] > rapport entre le sang et le sens, entre le ‘coup de sens’ et le ‘coup de sang’ [sens, sang, cent, sans]

OG.content: Martinet suggests replacing unity [bias] of word w/ “syntagm” (nothing to do w/ meaning), “group of several minimal signs” or “monemes”
OG.linkedContent: Martinet suggests replacing unity [bias] of word w/ “syntagm” (nothing to do w/ meaning), “group of several minimal signs” or “monemes”

OG.content: unity of sound & meaning (sens): reassuring closing (fermeture) of play
OG.linkedContent: unity of sound & meaning (sens): reassuring closing (fermeture) of play

OG.content: absolute parousia of literal meaning: presence to self of logos w/in voice
OG.linkedContent: absolute parousia of literal meaning: presence to self of logos w/in voice

OG.content: Rousseau: figurative language initiates and proper meaning is discovered last > eschatology of proper (self-presence, self-proximity, own-ness)
OG.linkedContent: Rousseau: figurative language initiates and proper meaning is discovered last > eschatology of proper (self-presence, self-proximity, own-ness)

FV.content: letter has no proper meaning, volante, volée; Lacan claims the letter isn’t content w/ having meaning > Derrida intends to show that w/ Lacan the letter is content to have one meaning, and one alone
FV.linkedContent: letter has no proper meaning, volante, volée; Lacan claims the letter isn’t content w/ having meaning > Derrida intends to show that w/ Lacan the letter is content to have one meaning, and one alone

FV.content: meaning of letter not important for Lacan? false! no one would worry about it if it didn’t have a determined meaning > meaning of letter for Lacan: betrayal of a pact
FV.linkedContent: meaning of letter not important for Lacan? false! no one would worry about it if it didn’t have a determined meaning > meaning of letter for Lacan: betrayal of a pact
